facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890 leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

anchor.surface_text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya. Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.

facts.text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath. Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914.

facts.text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya in 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son, and grandson

facts.text: Jagannath died in the year 1914.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son, and grandson

facts.text: Gangabai survived both her son and grandson.

anchor.surface_text: After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son, and grandson adopted the plaintiff, and thus raised the problem which we are called upon to solve.

facts.text: Plaintiff Dattatraya Gurunath claims he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai widow of Krishtarao.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya Gurunath, the plaintiff, claims that he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao. Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th of March, 1944 the appellant instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises in forma pauperis on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao and adopted to him by Gangabai,

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed possession of adoptive father's properties comprised in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: his junior widow, and as such was entitled to the possession of his adoptive fathers properties comprised in the suit. He also claimed a declaration regarding the amount of compensation money payable

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed declaration regarding compensation money payable to plaintiff's family for land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: He also claimed a declaration regarding the amount of compensation money payable to the plaintiffs family for the land acquired by Hubli Municipality. The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first

facts.text: Defendants are sons and grandsons of first cousin of Krishtarao.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first cousin of Krishtarao disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913,

facts.text: Defendants disputed plaintiff's adoption on ground Gangabai's power extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913, leaving behind him a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath who could continue the family line.

facts.text: Gangabai in written statement supported plaintiff's claim and asserted senior widow Radhabai gave consent to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent to her adopting the plaintiff. The trial judge upheld the defendants contention

facts.text: Trial judge upheld defendants' contention and dismissed plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent to her adopting the plaintiff. The trial judge upheld the defendants contention

facts.text: Trial judge upheld factum of plaintiff's adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld, and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent

facts.text: Trial judge held Radhabai did not give consent to the adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld, and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption. On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court

facts.text: High Court affirmed trial court decision.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

facts.text: High Court held Gangabai's power to adopt came to an end when her son died leaving a son and a widow.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

facts.text: High Court gave no finding on whether Radhabai gave consent to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: No finding was given on the question whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adoption. That perhaps would have been the simplest way to end the dispute. Against the decision of the High Court

facts.text: Appeal before Supreme Court by special leave in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave. The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption.

facts.text: Supreme Court held widow's power to adopt comes to an end by interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue the line.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

issues.text: whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son

anchor.surface_text: whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son. The situation in which this question arises can properly be appreciated by reference to the following genealogy Dyamappa ----------------------------------------- Kalasappa Girimaji Krishtarao Hanamanta Radhabai Gangabai --------------  Deft. 2   Deft. 1   Senior widow   Junior widow  Malhar Ganesh Gurunath  Resp. 3   Resp. 5  ------------------  Appellant adopted Kamalabai Yamunabai by Gangabai on Venkatesh Hanamant  Resp. 1   Resp. 2  18-11-53   Resp. 4   Resp. 6

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave. The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld, and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption. On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line. No finding was given on the question whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adoption.

issues.text: whether the limits laid down in these decisions have been arbitrarily fixed and are not based on sound principles and should be reviewed by us

anchor.surface_text: The question at what point of time the widows duty of continuing the line of the husband comes to an end had been the subject-matter of a number of decisions of Indian High Courts and of the Privy Council and the point for our consideration is whether the limits laid down in these decisions have been arbitrarily fixed and are not based on sound principles and should be reviewed by us.

arguments.claim: Once duty to continue line passed to son who passes to grandson or son's widow, mother's power gone permanently and cannot revive

anchor.surface_text: This argument, in our opinion, is not well founded as it is based on an incorrect apprehension of the true basis of the rule enunciated in this judgment, the rule being that where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to the grandson or to the sons widow, the mothers power is gone.

holdings.text: a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms long-standing rule from Privy Council and High Court decisions as integrated into Hindu law; no Shastric text mandates unlimited power; consistent with justice, equity, good conscience; rejects revival arguments.

holdings.text: the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law
holdings.reasoning_summary: Series of decisions over three quarters of a century have made the interposition rule part of Hindu law; too late to depart without substantial grounds.

holdings.text: in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience and ... the reasons stated in support of the rule are consistent with these principles
holdings.reasoning_summary: No clear Shastric limit exists but judicial limits upheld as consistent with justice, equity, good conscience; no substantial grounds shown for inequity.

holdings.text: it is too late in the day to say that there are no limitations of any kind on the widows power to adopt excepting those that limit the power of her husband to adopt
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bound by precedents; limitations exist beyond husband's power limits; interposition rule upheld.

holdings.text: Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies interposition rule to facts: Dattatraya died leaving Jagannath (grandson) and Sundarabai (son's widow); power extinguished permanently.

holdings.text: the validity of the plaintiffs adoption

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave. The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power extinguished in 1913; adoption in 1943 invalid despite factum upheld by trial court.

holdings.text: where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to the grandson or to the sons widow, the mothers power is gone
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects revival; duty passed permanently to next generation competent to continue line.

holdings.text: the ratio of the decision in Bapuji v. Gangaram was erroneous
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fallacious reasoning misapprehending Amarendra; duty ends permanently, no revival on removal of interposition.

holdings.text: The authority of [Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh] ... is considerably shaken by this error and even otherwise the decision gives no independent reasons
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows erroneous Nagpur case under misapprehension of Privy Council approval; no independent reasoning.

precedents.citation: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore  1865 10 M.I.A. 279

anchor.surface_text: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore  1865 10 M.I.A. 279  was delivered by Lord Kingsdown. What happened there was that one Gour Kishore died leaving a son Bhowanee and a widow, Chundrabullee, to whom he gave authority to adopt in the event of his sons death.

precedents.cited_proposition: Widow's power of adoption incapable of execution when son dies leaving a widow as heir
precedents.cited_holding: even if he had been in existence at the death of Bhowanee, he could not displace the widow of the latter

precedents.citation: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards  1881 L.R. 8 I.A. 229

anchor.surface_text: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards  1881 L.R. 8 I.A. 229  wherein a second effort to maintain the validity of his adoption by Chundrabullee was made but without success. The High Court in its judgment in Padma Coomaris case

precedents.case_name: Padma Coomari v Court of Wards
precedents.cited_proposition: upon the vesting of the estate in the widow of Bhowanee, the power of adoption of Chundrabullee was at an end
precedents.cited_holding: power of adoption was at an end and incapable of execution

precedents.case_name: Thayammal and Kuttiswami Aiyan v Venkatarama Aiyan

anchor.surface_text: Tarachurn v. Suresh Chunder  1889 L.R. 16 I.A. 166  decided in 1889. In the year 1902 this question came up for consideration before the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Ramkrishna Ramchandra v. Shamrao

precedents.cited_proposition: limitations upon the power of the widow to adopt

precedents.citation: Ramkrishna Ramchandra v. Shamrao  1902 I.L.R. 26 Bom 526

anchor.surface_text: Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Ramkrishna Ramchandra v. Shamrao  1902 I.L.R. 26 Bom 526 . There a grandmother succeeded to her grandson who died unmarried and it was held that her power to make an adoption had come to an end

precedents.cited_proposition: power of the former widow is extinguished and can never afterwards be revived
precedents.cited_holding: Where a Hindu dies leaving a widow and a son, and that son dies leaving a natural born or adopted son or leaving no son but his own widow to continue the line by means of adoption, the power of the former widow is extinguished

precedents.citation: Madana Mohana v. Purushothama Deo  1918 L.R. 45 I.A. 156

anchor.surface_text: This principle was approved and applied by the Judicial Committee in Madana Mohana v. Purushothama Deo  1918 L.R. 45 I.A. 156  in these words Their Lordships are in agreement with the principle laid down in the judgment of the Full Court of Bombay

precedents.cited_proposition: principle that authority to adopt comes to an end when son dies after attaining capacity to continue the line
precedents.cited_holding: the principle must be taken as applying so as to have brought the authority to adopt conferred on Adikondas widow to an end when Brojo, the son she originally adopted, died after attaining full legal capacity

precedents.citation: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan  1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 242

anchor.surface_text: most important decision of the Judicial Committee in regard to this matter was given in the year 1933 in Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan  1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 242  where there was a departure from or at least a reorientation of the old doctrine

precedents.cited_proposition: interposition of a grandson or sons widow brings mothers power of adoption to an end; power not dependent on vesting of property
precedents.cited_holding: where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father... has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to a grandson or to the sons widow, the mothers power is gone

anchor.surface_text: The rule enunciated in Amarendras case was subsequently applied in Vijaysingji v.
